title: Menorah with Nine Branches

adjectives: Of or relating to Jews or Judaism.
Of or relating to a Jew or Jews, their ethnicity, religion or culture.
Being a Jew, or relating to Jews, their ethnicity, religion or culture.
Of or relating to Jews or their culture or religion
nouns: The Hanukkah menorah or chanukiah is, strictly speaking, a nine-branched candelabrum lit during the eight-day holiday of Hanukkah, as opposed to the seven-branched menorah used in the ancient Temple or as a symbol.
A candelabrum with seven branches, a traditional symbol of Judaism
A nine-branched candelabrum used on the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, commemorating the above
A nine-branched menorah used during Hanukkah
(Judaism) a candelabrum with seven branches used in ceremonies to symbolize the seven days of Creation
A holy candelabrum with seven branches used in the Temple of Jerusalem.
Nine-branched candelabrum lit during the eight-day holiday of Hanukkah
A candle holder.
Branched candlestick; ornamental; has several lights
A candelabrum, sometimes called a candle tree, is a candlestick holder with multiple arms.

Hanukkah, also known as the Festival of Lights, Feast of Dedication, is an eight-day Jewish holiday commemorating the rededication of the Holy Temple in Jerusalem at the time of the Maccabean Revolt against the Seleucid Empire of the 2nd century BCE.
The Jewish festival.
(Judaism) an eight-day Jewish holiday commemorating the rededication of the Temple of Jerusalem in 165 BC
Jewish holiday
Jewish religious holiday
An eight-day Jewish holiday commemorating the rededication of the Temple of Jerusalem in 165 BC

Hanukkah, also known as the Festival of Lights, Feast of Dedication, is an eight-day Jewish holiday commemorating the rededication of the Holy Temple (the Second Temple) in Jerusalem at the time of the Maccabean Revolt against the Seleucid Empire of the 2nd century BCE.
An eight-day Jewish festival, starting on the 25th day of Kislev, which commemorates the rededication of the temple in Jerusalem after the victory of the Maccabees over the Greek Syrians.
Jews collectively who practice a religion based on the Torah and the Talmud
Judaism is the religion, philosophy, and way of life of the Jewish people.
A religion tracing its origin to the Hebrew people of the ancient Middle-East, as documented in their religious writings, the Torah or Old Testament.
Religion of the Jewish people
The character, philosophy, principles, or practices distinctive of the Hebrew people.
Judaism, is the religion, philosophy and way of life of the Jewish people.
An Abrahamic religion tracing its origin to the Hebrew people of the ancient Middle East, as documented in their religious writings, the Tanakh.
Candles are a traditional method of providing illumination, now superseded for most purposes by electric lightbulbs.
Slender wax candle.
A candle is a solid block of wax with an embedded wick which is ignited to provide light, and sometimes heat, and historically was used as a method of keeping time.
Solid block of wax with embedded wick
A light source consisting of a wick embedded in a solid, flammable substance such as wax, tallow, or paraffin.
Stick of wax with a wick in the middle
A slender wax candle; a small lighted wax candle; hence, a small light.

description: A menorah showing nine lit candles, used on the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah.
apple_vendor_description: The menorah emoji on Apple devices is a beautifully rendered, seven-branched candelabrum, depicted with a warm, golden brass finish that catches the light. Its elegant, curved arms and distinct candleholders are sculpted with Apple's signature glossy 3D shading, giving it a tangible, almost ceremonial feel. This emoji beautifully represents Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights, and is often used to convey themes of faith, miracles, and enduring hope during this Jewish holiday.
